question: Question_06
statement:
Let $n \in \mathbb{Z}$. Prove that $n \equiv 3 \pmod 5$ if and only if
$3n + 1$ is divisible by $5$.
sols:
Let us first assume that $n \equiv 3 \pmod 5$. This is equivalent to the
statement that $5 \mid (n - 3)$ or that there exists some integer $k$ so
that $n - 3 = 5k$ or that $n = 5k + 3$. In such a case, we have that

\begin{align*}3n + 1 = 3(5k + 3) + 1 = 5(3k) + 10 = 5(3k + 2)\end{align*}

and so since $3k+2$ is an integer, it follows that $5 \mid (3n + 1)$.

So suppose now that $5 \mid (3n+1)$; that is, there is some integer
$\ell$ so that $5 \ell = 3n + 1$. From this we can conclude that

\begin{align*}5\ell = 3n + 1 \iff 5(2\ell) = 6n + 2 = 5n + n + 5 - 3 = 5(n+1) + n - 3\end{align*}

Shifting the first of those terms to the other side we obtain that

\begin{align*}5 (2\ell - n - 1) = n - 3\end{align*}

Since $2\ell - n - 1$ is an integer, the result is proven.

Let us first show that if \emph{n} is congruent to 3 mod 5, then
3\emph{n}+1 is divisible by 5, that is, 3\emph{n}+1 is congruent to 0
mod 5.

Since we know that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle n \equiv 3 \pmod 5\end{align*} We can substitute this in the
expression of 3\emph{n}+1 and obtain that

\begin{align*}
3n+1 &\equiv 3(3)+1 \pmod 5\\
&\equiv 10 \pmod 5\\
&\equiv 0 \pmod 5\end{align*} Which proves that 3\emph{n}+1 is
divisible by 5.

Now, let's prove the converse, that is that if 3\emph{n}+1 is divisible
by 5, then \emph{n} is congruent to 3 mod 5.

We start with the fact that is 3\emph{n}+1 is divisible by 5, then it is
congruent to 0 mod 5 and write

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 3n+1 \equiv 0 \pmod 5\end{align*} Which we can rewrite as

\begin{align*}
3n &\equiv -1 \pmod 5\\
&\equiv 4 \pmod 5\end{align*} We would like to get some information
about \emph{n}, not 3\emph{n} but division in modular arithmetic is
tricky. In this case, since 3 and 5 are coprime, we know it can be done:
the inverse of 3 mod 5 is 2 since 2$\cdot$3=6 which is 1 mod 5. So we
multiply both sides of the equation by 2 and obtain

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 6n \equiv 8 \pmod 5\end{align*} And so since 6 is 1 mod 5 and 8 is
3 mod 5 we can conclude that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle n \equiv 3 \pmod 5\end{align*} Which shows that \emph{n} is
congruent to 3 mod 5 and finishes our proof.
hints:
Recall that the following are equivalent:

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $a \equiv b \pmod 5$
\item
  $5 \mid a - b$
\item
  There is some integer $k$ so that $5k = a - b$.
\end{enumerate}
